title: Omnichord
text:
The Omnichord is an electronic <a href="musical%20instrument">musical instrument</a> introduced in 1981 by the <a href="Suzuki%20Musical%20Instrument%20Corporation">Suzuki Musical Instrument Corporation</a>. It typically features a touch plate known as "SonicStrings", preset rhythms, auto-bass line functionality, and buttons for <a href="Major%20chord">major</a>, <a href="Minor%20chord">minor</a>, and <a href="Seventh%20chord">7th chords</a>. The most basic method of playing the instrument is to press the chord buttons and swipe the SonicStrings with a finger in imitation of strumming a stringed instrument. The SonicStrings may also be touched in one place to create a single note. Originally designed as an electronic <a href="Autoharp">Autoharp</a>, the Omnichord has become popular, due to its unique, chiming, <a href="harp">harp</a>like <a href="timbre">timbre</a> and its value as a <a href="kitsch">kitsch</a> object.
The Omnichord and its prototypes, the <a href="Tronichord">Tronichord</a> and Portachord (the latter two never reached full production) share many technical and functional similarities. Omnichords feature preset <a href="rhythm">rhythm</a>s with a <a href="tempo">tempo</a> and <a href="volume">volume</a> control, as well as an auto-bass line feature, actuated by a button, which the player may use as accompaniment. Several models of the Omnichord were produced that added <a href="MIDI">MIDI</a> compatibility, a selection of voices for the SonicStrings, <a href="vibrato">vibrato</a>, and chord memory. Some Omnichord musicians will play the <a href="musical%20instrument">instrument</a> as a <a href="keytar">keytar</a>, by strapping the instrument on both ends and playing it as if it were a <a href="Keytar">Keytar</a>.
The Omnichord is still produced by Suzuki, but rebadged as the Q-chord. It features more modern versions of the original Omnichord's features such as PCM sampled sounds, and more rhythms.
